important_phrase: Energy contacts continued to cite infrastructure expansion and high-capacity utilization
Wges and input prices continued to increase at a slow and steady pace
Contacts continued to report stable pricing with no major concerns about inflation
Mortgage lending and refinancing activity slowed as mortgage interest rates increased

Railroad contacts continued to cite significant increases in shipments of petroleum products and nonferrous scrap metals, as well as metallurgical coal; however, rail traffic year-to-date is up only slightly
District commercial brokers noted that demand for space continued to improve modestly
Sales of light vehicles were steady
Most firms are holding headcounts level; wages are steady or increasing modestly
Inventories are well managed and prices remain steady
The prospects for livestock producers improved due to reduced feed costs
Contacts remained hopeful for improvement in 2014, although they were slightly less optimistic than they were during the previous reporting period
Wge pressures were up slightly
Volatility decreased significantly across several asset classes and equity markets saw significant improvements
Part-time seasonal hiring for the holidays was slightly lower than normal, with retailers choosing to increase hours instead of hiring new workers
Overall demand for residential construction grew slightly, although remodeling activity slowed considerably
Sales of electronics were up, while grocery sales were flat, and apparel sales declined
Payrolls and wages held steady
The rate of decline in coal production is slowing
Demand for business credit grew slightly during the past six weeks
Factories expanded payrolls at a sluggish pace
Our contacts are cautiously optimistic about near-term prospects but are expecting slow growth at best
Projections for the fourth quarter call for flat to moderately higher sales relative to the same time period last year
Demand for oil-field services was steady despite the slight decline in the rig count as the number of wells drilled per rig continued to improve
Nonfinancial services firms reported steady to somewhat improved demand
One retail contact increased prices very modestly
Deposit volumes increased moderately with no change in deposit rates
High-tech manufacturers said demand was flat to modestly weaker over the past six weeks
Despite the slowdown, contacts were optimistic in their outlooks
Automobile sales were down slightly this reporting period, which contacts attributed to lack of consumer confidence and continued uncertainty
Crude oil prices moderated slightly from the previous survey, but remained generally strong
Consumer spending increased slightly, with retail stores moderately optimistic about future sales, and energy activity remained solid
Prices of manufacturing materials grew slower than in the previous period, and fewer firms planned on raising selling prices
Bankers reported steady overall loan demand, improved loan quality, and stable deposit levels in November
Employment conditions improved, with several respondents indicating plans to hire more skilled workers
Commercial real estate activity grew modestly, and contacts were increasingly optimistic heading forward
Consumer spending increased modestly from the previous period, and contacts were cautiously optimistic heading into the holiday season
Activity in the energy sector increased moderately, while mining was steady at a high level
Mining was steady at high levels, and agricultural conditions weakened slightly
Overall wage increases were moderate
A web technology firm noted that demand was strong and that profit margins were good
Residential construction activity increased
Consumer spending increased modestly
The Kansas City District indicated rising farmland values, although the rate of increase slowed
Reports from the twelve Federal Reserve Districts indicated that the economy continued to expand at a modest to moderate pace from early October through mid-November
Cleveland reported that year-over-year growth in retail holiday hiring is expected to be flat; however, some employers noted that they are having difficulty finding seasonal workers
Several Districts reported increased credit quality, as delinquencies have continued to decline and fewer problem loans have been reported
Manufacturing activity expanded at a modest to moderate pace in most Districts during the reporting period
Commercial real estate activity remained stable or improved slightly across many Districts
Consumer spending increased in almost all Districts at a modest to moderate pace
Contacts report that cost pressures have abated slightly, while selling prices are steady to up moderately

Small to medium sized banks across the Second District report decreased demand for consumer loans and residential mortgages but increased demand for commercial mortgages and commercial & industrial loans
Salary offers have reportedly increased slightly
Manhattan's rental market has also softened slightly, with rents running modestly lower than a year earlier
Consumer confidence in the region weakened in October
Despite a slower pace of growth in some sectors, contacts overall maintained an outlook for moderate growth--similar to the last Beige Book
Overall, Third District contacts reported no change to the steady, slight pace of price level increases, similar to the previous Beige Book
Overall, most bankers remained optimistic, albeit for continued slow, steady growth
Other service firms reported modest to moderate growth rates
Nonresidential real estate contacts indicated little change in the slight growth rate of construction and the modest pace of overall leasing activity
Pennsylvania dealers reported some softness during the government shutdown
Coal production has decreased slightly
The District economy expanded moderately in recent weeks
Employment conditions around the district improved slightly over the last several weeks
Consumer borrowing weakened slightly throughout the district since our last report
Prices in the service sector rose at a slower pace
Residential real estate markets slowed slightly in the past month
Auto sales remained solid, although a few dealers noted some slowing
Output in agricultural and resource-related industries expanded on balance
Demand for residential real estate expanded on net, and commercial real estate activity improved
Price pressures were limited for most final goods and services
Some slower growing regions experienced tepid growth of business investment that held back the pace of lending
Driven by demand for mobile technology products, business conditions in the semiconductor industry improved
Demand for residential real estate expanded on net, and commercial real estate activity improved
Retail sales were a bit soft
Wnter wheat planting was 87 percent complete, on average, across the District
Business activity in the Eighth District has expanded at a moderate pace since the previous report
In turn, 44 percent of contacts noted that wages over the past three months have stayed the same, while 52 percent noted that wages have increased
Credit standards and creditworthiness of applicants for auto loans and credit cards remained mostly unchanged, while demand decreased moderately and delinquencies edged down slightly
Reports of plans for manufacturing have been positive since our previous report
Residential construction also improved in many areas of the District
Some contacts noted fewer sales from low-income shoppers, and some contacts noted increases in lower-end product sales
